newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index falls at noon on A share slide.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index falls at noon on A share slide.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index was down at midday on Thursday on a slide in A shares caused by concerns that Beijing could take measures to cool the market down, analysts said.
The foreign currency B share index fell 3.12 points or 1.71 percent to 179.62 on turnover of HK$79.16 million.
"Investors are worrying that the B share market may be affected if the government imposes clampdown measures on the A share market," an analyst at J&A Securities said.
The domestic currency A share index dropped 9.77 points or 1.83 percent to 524.02 on turnover of 10.4 billion yuan after closing at an historic high of 533.78 points on Wednesday.
New B share offers diverted some funds from the B share market, analysts said.
"A lot of our customers are selling their stocks in preparation for subscribing to the new share offerings," the J&A analyst said.

Pesticide maker Hubei Sanonda Co Ltd, Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Ltd and Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Equipment Co Ltd have announced they will each offer 100 million B shares for listing in Shenzhen this month.
But analysts also said they expected the three new stocks to perform well on their listing debuts, which are likely to boost sentiment.
"Investors are grabbing any new share issues, likening them to money trees," the analyst said.
The B index is unlikely to fall much further in the next few sessions, analysts said.

"The B index is supported by the 10 day average of 178 points," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said. "There should be a period of fluctuation in the near future given the wary mood, but the big picture still shines."

China's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to grow 9.6 percent year-on-year in the first half of 1997, with retail price inflation seen at two percent, an official newspaper on Tuesday quoted a forecast by the State Economic and Trade Commission as saying.
Television tube maker Shenzhen SEG Co Ltd was the sharpest loser in the B share market, falling HK$0.70 or 6.86 percent to HK$9.50.
